name: Equality operator
content: Your apps will sometimes need to check if the values in their code are equivalent or not, and then possibly perform some specific action using an *if*, *if-else*, or *while* block. *==* returns true if the value on the left-hand side of the operator is equal to the value on the right-hand side of the operator.

examples.name: Example: Basic numeric equality check
Example: "Alan Turing" equals "ALAN TURING"?
examples.description: Basic string equality check. Case matters for string comparison.

examples.name: Example: 5 equals "5"?
examples.description: Numeric string to number conversion is automatic in App Lab.

examples.name: Example: 5 equals "five"?
examples.description: Word string to number conversion is not automatic in App Lab.

palette_params.description: The operands can be a number/string/boolean, or a variable containing a number/string/boolean, or the number/string/boolean returned by a function, or the number/string/boolean result of the evaluation of an expression.

return_value: Boolean (true/false) is the left equal in value to the right.
short_description: Tests whether two values are equal.
tips:
- = is the assignment operator. == is the boolean check for equivalency operator.
- JavaScript will automatically perform type conversion for you when comparing two values (e.g. the integer 5 will register as equivalent to the string "5").
- Comparison operators include < <= == > >= !=
